comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: A similar shot in the PHM collection but the little building out the front isn't there (is it a police box or for the trams perhaps? I can't zoom in to read it! www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2666198817/ And City of Sydney Archives www3.photosau.com/cos1/scripts/home.asp Just a quick guess without actually doing any in depth research at the moment. I'm thinking that this appears to be post the 1903 renovations. Going by the clothes and the lack of cars I would guess that this image would not have been taken much later than c1915, but my gut says earlier. Still haven't managed to find any other pics with the little building out front either. Anyone else?

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: The sign attached to the little hut says "Forest Lodge Races, Every Monday"....that might help with the date.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: "FOREST LODGE RACES, EVERY MONDAY" - Thanks Rhonda, it certainly has ... [Posted here as too many links to be accepted by the Archives Outside blog] The Forest Lodge Pony and Galloway races were held at Forest Lodge (formerly known as Lillie Bridge) every MONDAY between December 1899 and May 1903. They were first held on Monday 25 December 1899, with the last reported weekly Monday race being held on Monday 25 May 1903. The trotting track was bought by Sir James John Joynton Smith in 1903 and renovated and renamed Epping. Newspapermen were given a tour of the new racecourse when renovations were complete in June 1904. Thereafter the weekly Pony and Galloway trotting races were run on FRIDAYS, the first on Friday 1 July 1904. I imagine those intending to catch a tram to the races would wait by the hut, as this would correspond to the tram routes mentioned (in the previous link): "Trams (Forest Lodge and Balmain) will leave Circular Quay, via George Street". So, taking all this into consideration with Walter Liberty Vernon's Customs House rebuild completed in 1903, I think we can safely say: 1903 it is! [With thanks to the wonderful digitised newspaper resources of Trove]

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: Wow! Which is Harold Park Paceway today. According to the website racing occured at Forest Lodge for only two meetings after it's opening in November 1902 then the races moved to Kensington until they returned in 1904, when the track was called Epping until 1929. But a quick search of Trove clearly shows newspaper articles mentioning 'Forest Lodge Races' on Mondays from 1899 to 25 December 1903. After this there are no references to this but in 1904 there begin to be mentions of the Epping Race Club in 'The Turf' section of SMH - which I'm presuming means at Forest Lodge. So I propose that the photo is 1903 to 1904 based on this - what does everyone think?

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] oh this is too funny - I had been researching the above answer for about half an hour, hit post & there appeared your comment just above mine! Touche :-)

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/agrippinamaior] Great minds think alike! - but I spent longer than half an hour :) I think the two race meetings mentioned on the Harold Park Raceway website, are only those held under the auspices of the New South Wales Trotting Club, before their move to Kensington. I too found the 25 December 1903 article, but that race was on a Thursday not a Monday. I found no Monday races reported in June 1903, so that is why I thought the "Every Monday" races had stopped in May, but now I see Monday meets resumed briefly later in June under the auspices of the Tradesman Trotting and Racing Club, after a short break. I can't see any more reported after Monday 29 June 1903. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14563071 PS. I wish I could have made it to Melbourne to see your latest exhibition ... the photos you posted were amazing. I've always been to scared to photograph people in the street. I have no dramas with buildings :)

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: They do! Yes I think you must be right about the races. Quite funny that the site doesn't even acknowledge the existence of racing there prior!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/agrippinamaior] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Good work! I get the same date (late 1903 / early 1904) using a different method - I notice that there are no electric street lights (approved for Circular Quay area in October 1904 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14637029) ). An early street lamp is visible to the left of the tramway pylon on the other photo mentioned above (by agrippinamaior) at full zoom - from.ph/28422 , but not here. The older gas lamp and bollards by the shed are evident in this photo but not the later one. Due to the shortness of the shadows (at 11.01 am) and the clothes (Mary Poppins' parasol ! ) it must be summer, as Robert Mills posted on the blog. [pretentious comment alert} The photographer has used the tram wires and lines extremely effectively to emphasize the perspectives of the newly-completed Customs House. Like an architectural drawing. I bet it was John Degotardi Jnr. (See also the next photo) [alert over]

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] ah I wish you could have come down to see the exhibition too! Thanks so much! Sometimes I photograph people confidently, other times I feel that it's just not right. I didn't do much other street photography with so many people in them in the rest of South America, except in La Paz, but San Telmo was too compelling not too!

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] thanks! I was wondering about the electric streetlights but went the way of the races. I couldn't see any electricity but wasn't sure about the dates for it :-) I like you're identification of the John Degotardi Jnr pics too. I think you mentioned in another photo some research about him?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/agrippinamaior]  I know almost zilch about photography, photographers, and photographic history, but I sense a particular style and quality in many of these Public Works Department photos which points to John Degotardi Junior.  The use of composition, perspectives, light and shade, and sometimes people is remarkable and consistent.  He seems to be an unsung hero, possibly in the shadow of his father, and maybe seen as just a staff 'hack' photographer at the Public Works Department.  My purpose is to give credit where credit is due!  There is a thesis, exhibition, and coffee table book waitiing to happen . . .

So when does said Thesis/exhibition/book happen? Go on, there's a couple of people who be great supervisors for you :D

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: HOW SHE CAME BY HER NAME by beachcomberaustralia Act I, Scene I [At the Department of Public Works, one fine day in the summer of 1903 -4] W.L. Vernon (The Boss) - "John Junior, your job for the day: I want you to go down to Circular Quay and photograph my new extensions to the Customs House, now the builders have left at last, and before all those confounded pigeons make a mess of it, and the City Council cover the building with electric lamp-posts. See if you can avoid all those infernal tramway wires - they are so hideous." John Junior (the photographer) - "Right-Oh, Mr Vernon. Can I take my sandwiches and have my lunch there please?" W.L.V. - "Oh, I suppose so. But be back by one o'clock. I want the photograph on my desk this afternoon." Later, that same day . . . J.J. - "Mr Vernon, here is the photograph you asked for. I am sorry, it was impossible to avoid the tram wires, but I think I used them to good effect. But a strange lady with a parasol and no feet popped in from nowhere and hovered above the tram lines. Then she popped off on her merry way. I am spitting mad that the camera spotted her" W.L.V - "Let's call her Mary Poppins - Spit spot ! " J.J. - "That's Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious, Mr Vernon . . . " THE END

comment.author: 20958381@N08

comment._content: HOLD YOUR HORSES ! STOP THE PRESSES ! . . . This could be the summer of 1902-03! It seems the Customs House (exterior at least) might have been finished a year earlier as this picture from another direction shows. I dated it as September 1902 from the banner on the Belmore Hotel. The Customs House looks complete, and the wooden hut has the SAME poster on the other side. See full zoom here - from.ph/31929 . The two photos are not contemporary due to the length of the shadows. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/4903285467/] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/agrippinamaior] - I think the hut is something to do with the trams - there are points there - see the six tramlines in these photos. So, 1902, 1903, 1904, or c.1903? Any more opinions?
